title: Plane Wave Propagation Time
description: Calculate the time required for a plane wave to reach a specified point.
question_text: How long does it take a plane wave, passing through the origin with a wavefront normal at 10° from the positive z-axis, to reach a point at (x0, z0) = (3, 6)? Use c = 3e8 m/s as the speed of light.

steps: Determine the unit propagation vector. Since the wavefront normal makes a 10° angle with the positive z-axis, the unit vector is n = (sin(10°), cos(10°)).
Write the displacement vector from the origin to the point: r = (3, 6).
Project r onto n to find the effective travel distance: distance = 3*sin(10°) + 6*cos(10°).
Divide the distance by the speed of light (c = 3×10^8 m/s) to find the time: t ≈ 6.43 / (3×10^8) ≈ 2.14×10^-8 s, or about 21.4 nanoseconds.

title: Plane Wave Propagation Time
description: Calculate the time required for a plane wave, with a given propagation direction, to reach a specified point.
question_text: How long does it take a plane wave, passing through the origin with a wavefront normal at 10° from the positive z-axis, to reach a point at (x0, z0) = (5, 10)? Use c = 3e8 m/s as the speed of light.

steps: Determine the unit propagation vector. Since the wavefront normal makes a 10° angle with the positive z-axis, the unit vector is n = (sin(10°), cos(10°)).
Write the displacement vector from the origin to the point: r = (5, 10).
Project r onto n to find the effective travel distance: distance = 5*sin(10°) + 10*cos(10°).
Divide the distance by the speed of light (c = 3×10^8 m/s) to find the time: t ≈ 10.72 / (3×10^8) ≈ 3.57×10^-8 s, or about 35.7 nanoseconds.

title: Match Physical Quantities with MKS Units
description: Match physical quantities with MKS unit.
question_text:
Name the MKS units of the following quantities:  
1. Intensity  
2. Exposure  
3. Power  
4. Energy

solution.final_answer:
Intensity (W/m²) power per unit area.  
Exposure (J/m²) energy per unit area.  
Power (W) energy per unit time  
Energy (J) joules
